narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In this course, we did a lot of memorization rather than learning and internalizing the vocabulary and grammar of the Spanish language. It was really disappointing that I felt my Spanish skills deteriorate in L2 since we mostly prepared scripts and recited them rather than practicing our fluency.
I learned a lot of spanish vocabulary and improved my pronunciation.
More Spanish grammar, especially imperfect, subjunctive, perfect, and future tense. More Spanish vocab on health, neighborhoods/around the home, work, and the environment.
Practice with reading, writing, and listening to Spanish.
new verb tenses and vocabulary. Also improving reading in Spanish as well as conversing.

The syllabus is promising, but the reality is underwhelming. Prof. Santos rarely thought us anything. I sometimes tried counting how many sentences of Spanish she would use in her monologues, and rarely went past ten in one class. What you learn in class is solely based on your commitment to self-study and your resilience to the chaos the professor brings.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I cannot think of a single strength of this class, but there are a million weaknesses that come to mind. The presentations throughout the semester were ridiculous in their emphasis on memorization over comprehension. And, many of the themes that students proposed for their presentations were rejected. So, we were doing research and presenting about content that didn't actually intrigue us at all. This class was miserable and I dreaded it every single day. It honestly always left me shaking and feeling so uncomfortable about the concept of having to return every Mon/Wed/Fri.
One weakness is that it is a lot of work, and since it was online I did not speak in Spanish as much. However, one strength was that the class was pretty collaborative.

I think it could be really stressful, especially with memorizing the presentations and frequent testing. It felt like there was always at least one high-pressure assessment per week, which was very stressful to have.
Our professor could've actually prepared lesson slides and reinforced the material instead of solely asking us to do independent work.
Strengths: breakout rooms helped with getting to know classmates and improving my Spanish speaking. Weakness: the online format made it difficult to learn a language

SPAN 120 with Prof. Santos has been the worst class I've taken at Yale. It is best described as chaotic zoom meetings three times a week, in which the professor babbles about mid-century modernism, and then puts students in breakout rooms without a clear agenda. Outside of class, we'd sometimes be greeted by passive-agressive emails such as one with the subject line "Not a good idea to miss class today... ;-)" and no content. Conversely, in class Prof. Santos would also pull us out of our breakout rooms one by one for what could have been an email.

The professor would often snap at students for trivial matters, such as a student being a second late to class (on that occasion, she spent minutes lecturing us how every *nanosecond* of class time is precious...) 

Class time was either incredibly chill or incredibly stressful with no middle ground. Some times we would all be in one big breakout room "dancing" to cha-cha and studying for actual classes. Other times, the professor would somehow delete our slides during class presentations, and then call us out for not having them in the shared google doc. Other times, she would call us out on not turning in an assignment due days later just because "her other section has already done it."

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I appreciated that the class met only three times a week instead of five.
I wish that we spoke in Spanish more.
I liked the asynchronous days a lot, but many of the asynchronous days were spent doing tests synchronously.

We were put in breakout rooms way too often instead of being instructed by our professor. Much of our class time felt wasted, and if we were in person, I doubt we would've had so little engagement with the professor.
The two asynchronous days were super helpful in learning new material or practicing for the live classes.
This class induced more stress and anxiety than the COVID-19 pandemic itself.

The class's heavy reliance on breakout rooms in a zoom call and lack of clear instructor guidance lead to the class failing to meaningfully impart anything that could not have been learned independently.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it is important to learn Spanish.

No, I would not, not unless they were required to complete L2 Spanish. Professor Santos was not clear, not very accommodating, and did not enhance my Spanish learning. I had to teach myself for most of the course.
If you need a language Spanish at yale is difficult but rewarding. I would recommend if you already have some background knowledge or are really interesting in Spanish language/culture.
I would not wish a Spanish section with Prof. Santos even on my worst enemy. Take the class with another professor instead.

No, this was the worst class I have ever taken at Yale by a large margin, not because of the difficulty of the class itself or the material it covered, but rather the poor format and the quality of the instructor.
